docs.lead_paragraph: Whether it's through drinking too hard or driving too fast, or picking fights with fists or pistols, men as a rule are said to engage in more self-destructive behaviors than women. But why should women bother, when their bodies so often do the self-destructing for them?

headline.main: Researchers Piecing Together Autoimmune Disease Puzzle

docs.abstract: Researchers are just beginning to understand why women are far more vulnerable than men to long and varied list of autoimmune diseases, in which body's immune system attacks one or more of body's organs; conditions range from cosmetically annoying to debilitating to severe, progressive and even fatal; one factor seems to be exchange of body cells during pregnancy between mother and fetus; researchers are also devising novel ways to block misguided attacks and let scapegoated organs heal; efforts include new study led by Denise L Faustman in which mice were cured of Type 1 diabetes with injections of drug that induces body to produce tumor necrosis factor, which in turn caused aberrant autoimmune cells to self-destruct and let islet cells of pancreas regrow; diagrams; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Whether it's through drinking too hard or driving too fast, or picking fights with fists or pistols, men as a rule are said to engage in more self-destructive behaviors than women.     But why should women bother, when their bodies so often do the...

docs.lead_paragraph: She remembers hearing the word thalidomide half a lifetime ago, when she was a young mother in Queens and it was a pharmaceutical scourge that maimed children. Now, Geraldine A. Ferraro punches a single tablet of thalidomide through a foil seal before she goes to bed every night. She swallows the pill that once was banned around the world, then sleeps like a rock for eight solid hours.

headline.main: Ferraro Is Battling Blood Cancer With a Potent Ally: Thalidomide

docs.abstract: Geraldine A Ferraro discloses that she is has been diagnosed with multiple myeloma, blood cancer that erodes bones and leads to death within 5 years for half of those with diagnosis; is taking thalidomide; will testify about her illness at Senate hearing this week; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mothers may or may not be able to teach their babies French in the womb, but they apparently can help them develop a taste for carrots by drinking carrot juice during pregnancy, an article in the current issue of Pediatrics reports. On the other hand, the researchers also found that mothers could get the same head start on building a healthy palate by breast-feeding and drinking carrot juice.
docs.abstract: Study finds mothers can help babies develop taste for carrots by drinking carrot juice during pregnancy or when they are breast-feeding; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dana Wechsler Linden and Emma Trenti Paroli exchanged nervous glances in a neonatal intensive care unit, they never expected that they would be embarking on a four-year career journey together. They met nearly five years ago when their newborns were roommates in a New York City hospital. The two women commiserated about the anxiety and loneliness that parents of preemies sometimes experience.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH: Dana Wechsler Linden, Emma Trenti Paroli and Mia Wechsler Doron; Offering Comfort and Information To the Parents of Preemies

docs.abstract: Interview with Dana Wechsler Linden and Emma Trenti Paroli, journalists and mothers of premature babies, and Dr Mia Wechsler Doron, authors of book on prematurity; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a victory for women's-rights groups -- and all working women who spend hundreds of their own dollars a year on birth-control pills -- a Federal judge in Seattle ruled that Bartell Drug Co. engaged in sex discrimination by offering health insurance that covered male employees' basic health needs, but excluded the prescription contraceptives that women use. The judge said that under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, ''the law is no longer blind to the fact that only women can get pregnant, bear children or use prescription contraception.'' Tamar Lewin

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN my girlfriend of only six months pulled me into her bathroom and showed me the telltale second pink line on a home pregnancy test, the last thing either of us thought about was marriage. We were still disentangling ourselves from recent exes, other marriage proposals (hers) and various bad habits (mine). Our thoughts ran toward, Are we even going to have this baby? How can we? Are we ready for this? Both of us were in our mid-30's. Clocks were ticking, but this was terrifying. What if she took our baby and ran off with her ex? She meanwhile worried whether she could really count on me. Or whether I would take off on my next freelance assignment and be out of touch. I wasn't exactly somebody who had mastered commitment. The longest I had ever lived with anyone was seven months, with a woman in Santa Fe who shot rats with a pistol.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal trial judge in Washington State ruled this week that a local family-owned drugstore chain had engaged in unlawful sex discrimination by excluding contraceptive coverage from its employee health plan. As a technical matter, the ruling is binding on only that one company. But the ruling -- the first time a court has addressed the issue of gender equity in drug coverage -- sets a legally solid precedent that may well encourage more health coverage of contraceptives nationwide. The issue caught fire a few years ago after it was discovered that many employers who excluded women's prescription contraceptives from coverage chose to pay for Viagra, the prescription drug to treat impotence in men. The class action suit, brought under the pregnancy discrimination provisions of Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, challenged an obvious inequity -- the fact that the health insurance coverage offered by the chain paid for all the basic health care needs of male employees while selectively excluding the cost of birth-control pills or other forms of contraception. Judge Robert S. Lasnik found that Congress, in amending Title VII in 1978 to bar pregnancy discrimination, intended to outlaw any discrimination against women ''in the terms and conditions of their employment, including the benefits an employer provides to its employees.'' He added that men and women had different health care needs and that ''the law is no longer blind to the fact that only women can get pregnant, bear children, or use prescription contraception.''
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes ruling by Judge Robert S Lasnik of federal court in Washington State that local family-owned drugstore chain engaged in unlawful sex discrimination by excluding contraceptive coverage from its employee health plan; hopes this encourages opposition to Bush administration's attempt to end contraceptive coverage for federal employees, and affects New York State, where bill that would require Catholic hospitals and schools to provide female employees insurance coverage for contraceptives is stalled because of strong opposition from Cardinal Edward Egan

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12. Now Playing ''THE ANIMAL.'' Starring Rob Schneider and Colleen Haskell. Directed by Luke Greenfield (PG-13, 83 minutes). The goofy new Rob Schneider comedy isn't the gross-out farce that its title suggests. The star portrays a meek, much-persecuted police department file clerk who, after being implanted with animal organs after a near-fatal car accident, fights against the instincts of the donor beasts that rise up inside him. Especially when he goes into a mating dance with a female goat and feeds a bird (bird-style) in an animal shelter, this fable about the dog beneath the skin is very funny. Mr. Schneider brings an endearing innocence to a role that others would have played with a nasty leer (Stephen Holden).
